paper_title: Self-assembly of highly-dispersed phosphotungstic acid clusters onto graphitic carbon nitride nanosheets as fascinating molecular-scale Z-scheme heterojunctions for photocatalytic solar-to-fuels conversion

catalyst.source: Herein, we synthesized phosphotungstic acid/graphitic carbon nitride (HPW/g-C 3 N 4 ) heterojunction nanosheets (NSs) with the highly-dispersed distribution of ultra-small HPW clusters (12 nm) by using a facile self-assembly method based on the static adsorption-deposition process.
catalyst.context: Rational assembly of small-sized photosensitizers onto 2D semiconductors can effectively promote the photocatalytic activity of the formed 2D heterojunction photocatalyst due to the hetero-interfacial charge-transfer process.However, the achievement of the 2D semiconductor-based heterojunction photocatalyst with the exposures of both abundant light-harvesting and catalytic sites at the hetero-interface region is still a huge challenge.Herein, we synthesized phosphotungstic acid/graphitic carbon nitride (HPW/g-C 3 N 4 ) heterojunction nanosheets (NSs) with the highly-dispersed distribution of ultra-small HPW clusters (12 nm) by using a facile self-assembly method based on the static adsorption-deposition process.The formed molecular-scale heterointerface between HPW clusters and g-C 3 N 4 NSs resulted in the exposure of abundant active-sites on the highlydispersed HPW/g-C 3 N 4 hetero-interface.By combining the steady-state and transient photoluminescence spectra with the wavelength-controlled experiments, we demonstrated that the hetero-interfacial charge-transfer process occurring in the HPW/g-C 3 N 4 heterojunction NSs obeyed the Z-scheme mechanism rather than the common "type-II" heterojunction mechanism.In this way, the lifetimes of photoinduced electrons on the conduction band of g-C 3 N 4 could be prolonged for initiating the photocatalytic solar-to-fuels conversion.Upon interband excitations of both the two hetero-components in the HPW/g-C 3 N 4 heterojunction NSs, the photocatalytic activities of H 2 generation and CO 2 reduction could be enhanced by 2.2 and 6.7 times as compared to the pure g-C 3 N 4 NSs, even though the HPW component was photocatalytic-inert for either H 2 generation or CO 2 reduction upon UV-vis light irradiation.

The g-C 3 N 4 was prepared by a traditional thermal polymerization method.Typically, 10 g of carbamide powder was lapped for 60 min in a mortar and then transferred to a 50 mL alumina crucible with a cover.Subsequently, the crucible was heated to 550 C with a rising rate of 18 C/min and kept for 2 h at 550 C, thereby obtaining the g-C 3 N 4 bulk with faint-yellow color. Typically, 100 mg g-C 3 N 4 bulk was ultrasonically dispersed into the deionized water to form the suspension solution of g-C 3 N 4 NSs.Then, the pH value of g-C 3 N 4 suspension solution was adjusted to 3.1 by dropwise adding 1.2 M of HCl solution.Afterward, 5, 10, 20, 30 mg of HPW were dissolved in deionized water and then added the obtained HPW solution to the g-C 3 N 4 suspension solution with vigorous stirring for 2 h.The weight ratio of HPW to g-C 3 N 4 was determined to be 5, 10, 20, and 30 wt., respectively.Subsequently, the mixture was separated by the centrifugal treatment, and dried at 70 C for 12 h to obtain the g-C 3 N 4 NSs loaded with different amount of HPW.Finally, the HPWloaded g-C 3 N 4 NSs were annealed at 300 C for 2 h under the vacuum condition, thereby synthesizing the HPW/g-C 3 N 4 heterojunction NSs. According to the first-principles calculations and analyses, we synthesized the HPW/g-C 3 N 4 heterojunction NSs through a facile threestep route (Fig. 2A): (i) the synthesis of the g-C 3 N 4 NSs by combining a traditional thermal polymerization method with the followed ultrasonic exfoliation treatment; (ii) the assembly of highly-dispersed HPW clusters onto the surfaces of g-C 3 N 4 NSs based on the electrostatic interaction force between HPW and g-C 3 N 4 ; (iii) the heat treatment of the HPW-adsorbed g-C 3 N 4 NSs to strengthen the chemical bonding at their hetero-interface, and thus obtaining the HPW/g-C 3 N 4 heterojunction NSs.During the synthesis process, we, at first, adjusted the surface charges of the g-C 3 N 4 NSs into the positive polarity for adsorbing the negatively-charged Keggin units in the aqueous solution.As shown in Fig. S1, the zeta potential of the as-synthesized g-C 3 N 4 NSs depends on pH value of the aqueous solution suspended with g-C 3 N 4 NSs.Particularly, the surface charges of the g-C 3 N 4 NSs could be changed into the positive polarity when the pH value of the suspension solution was adjusted below 4.5.Thus, a homogeneous dissolution of HPW molecules into the above g-C 3 N 4 NSs-suspended solution would induce a self-assembly of highly-dispersed HPW clusters on the surface of the g-C 3 N 4 NSs due to the electrostatic adsorption process between the negatively-charged PW 12 O 40 3-groups of HPW molecules and the positively-charged g-C 3 N 4 NSs.In order to reinforce the hetero-interface quality in the obtained HPW/g-C 3 N 4 composite NSs, the followed heattreatment process was carried out.It could further strengthen the chemical bonding at their hetero-interface, and leading to the formation of the HPW/g-C 3 N 4 heterojunction NSs in the viewpoint of chemical kinetics and solid state physics 23242526. Fig. 2B shows the X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns of the as-synthesized samples.For the sample of the g-C 3 N 4 NSs, two diffraction peaks appear at 13.1and 27.4, which can be indexed to the (100) and (002) planes of g-C 3 N 4 , respectively 7,8,15,27.For the sample of HPW, the diffraction peaks at 1012, 1622, 2330and 3140a re attributed to the typical HPW with a Keggin structure, which have ever been reported in previous literature 15.However, the characteristic diffraction peaks of HPW could not be observed in the XRD patterns of HPW/g-C 3 N 4 heterojunction NSs, even though the mass ratio of HPW to g-C 3 N 4 was increased from 5 wt. to 30 wt..This phenomenon may be attributed to the fact that the ultra-small sized HPW units were highly dispersed on the surface of the g-C 3 N 4 NSs, thereby leading to a poor crystal-diffraction signal beyond the XRD probing limit. In order to ensure the co-existence of HPW and g-C 3 N 4 component in the heterojunction NSs, we investigated the Fourier transform infrared (FT-IR) spectra of the as-synthesized samples (Fig. 2B,C).For the pure g-C 3 N 4 NSs, the peaks located at 3400 cm -1 to 3000 cm -1 are attributed to stretching vibration of -NH 2 and NH amino groups, while several weak peaks ranging from 1700cm -1 to 1120 cm -1 are assigned to the stretching vibration modes of CeN and CN bonds in CN heterocycles.And, the peak at 812 cm -1 is related to the feature vibration mode of s-triazine ring unit 17,28.In the case of HPW, the feature vibration modes of keggin units are located at 1080.1 cm -1 , 981.76 cm -1 , 889.18 cm -1 , and 802.38 cm -1 , which denote the P-O a bonds of the PO 4 tetrahedron, the W O d bonds, and the two W-O b/c -W bonds, respectively 17.After coupling HPW with g-C 3 N 4 , the characteristic vibrational peaks related to both the g-C 3 N 4 NSs and HPW could be found simultaneously on the FT-IR spectrum of the formed HPW/g-C 3 N 4 heterojunction NSs.As compared to the pure HPW, the three characteristic peaks related to Keggin units (WO d bonds, and two WeO b/c eW bonds) are shifted to 979.83 cm -1 , 893.04 cm -1 , and 812.03 cm -1 , respectively, on the FT-IR spectrum of the HPW/g-C 3 N 4 heterojunction NSs.This phenomenon suggests the existence of chemical interaction between HPW and g-C 3 N 4 in their heterojunction NSs produced by the static adsorption-deposition method and subsequent vacuum annealing treatment. To determine in-depth the chemical interaction between the HPW and the g-C 3 N 4 components in their heterojunction NSs, the X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) analyses of the as-synthesized samples were implemented.As observed in Fig. 3A, three feature peaks, corresponding to sp 2 CeC bonds (284.6 eV), sp 3 -coordinated carbon bonds (285.4 eV), and N-bonded sp 2 C-atom in the s-triazine (NeCN) (287.8 eV) 29,30, can be detected on the C 1s core-level spectrum of the pure g-C 3 N 4 NSs.However, the feature peaks of the sp 3 -coordinated carbon bonds and the NeCN bonds on the spectrum of the 20 wt. HPW/g-C 3 N 4 heterojunction NSs shift to the higher binding energy side as compared to the corresponding peaks of the pure g-C 3 N 4 NSs.In addition, a new peak with the binding energy at around 286.2 eV was observed, which could be ascribed to the formation of CeO bands 31,32.Fig. 3B displays the N 1s core-level spectra of the 20 wt. HPW/g-C 3 N 4 heterojunction NSs in comparison with the g-C 3 N 4 NSs.It is obvious that the binding energies of the sp 2 -bonded N (CeNC), tertiary nitrogen N-(C) 3 groups, and amino groups (CeNeH) 8,33,34 on the spectrum of the heterojunction NSs are also higher than the corresponding energies on the spectrum of the pure g-C 3 N 4 .The O 1s core-level spectra of the pure HPW and the 20 wt. HPW/g-C 3 N 4 heterojunction NSs are given in Fig. 3C.The two feature peaks on the spectrum of the pure HPW are originated from to the WeOeW (530.8 eV) and WeOeP/WeOeH bonds (531.9 eV), respectively 17.In the case of 20 wt. HPW/g-C 3 N 4 heterojunction NSs, the above two peaks also shift toward the higher binding energy side as compared to the pure HPW.Interestingly, the two new peaks attributed to the CeOeW (532.6 eV) and C(N) 3 -OH (533.7 eV) bonds 17,18,35, can be found on the O 1s core-level spectrum of the heterojunction NSs.The appeared C(N) 3 -OH bonds in the 20 wt. HPW/g-C 3 N 4 heterojunction NSs could be attributed to the substitution of the amino groups by the hydroxyl groups after the acidizing treatment of g-C 3 N 4 NSs 17,18, thereby leading to the formation of N defects.Meanwhile, the observation of the CeOeW bond is consistent with the DFT calculation results, further confirming that the HPW and g-C 3 N 4 in their heterojunction NSs are linked by the CeOeW bond.Notably, the W 4f 7/2 and W 4f 5/2 peaks of the pure HPW located at 35.8 and 37.9 eV 17,18, respectively, are shifted to the lower binding energy sides after forming the HPW/g-C 3 N 4 heterojunction (Fig. 3D).According to the previous reports, the binding energy shifts on the XPS spectra of the HPW/g-C 3 N 4 heterojunction NSs can be ascribed to the electron transfer across the HPW/g-C 3 N 4 hetero-interface through the formed CeOeW bond due to the different electron concentration between the two heterocomponents.Additionally, the P 2p core-level signal could be also detected on the XPS spectrum of HPW/g-C 3 N 4 heterojunction NSs, as shown in Fig. S3.The binding energy peak centered at 133.8 eV indicates the existence of P 5 in the oxidation state 15,18, which is in agreement with the valence state of P in the HPW.It further demonstrates that the HPW/g-C 3 N 4 heterojunction NSs were constructed through the self-assembly method based on the static adsorption-deposition process. The light absorption properties of the as-synthesized samples were investigated through UV-vis adsorption spectra, and the corresponding results were shown in Fig. 6 and S5.It can be observed that the pure g-C 3 N 4 NSs possess a broad light-absorption range spanning from UV-to visible-light region.However, the pure HPW only displays a UV-light adsorption property.The band gap (E g ) values of the pure g-C 3 N 4 NSs and HPW were calculated to be 2.75 eV and 3.01 eV, which are consistent with the literatures 12,40.After coupling the g-C 3 N 4 NSs with the HPW clusters, the formed HPW/g-C 3 N 4 heterojunction NSs exhibited the blue-shifts of absorption edges as compared to the g-C 3 N 4 NSs.What' more, the blue-shift phenomenon for the absorption edge of the HPW/g-C 3 N 4 heterojunction NSs increased gradually with increasing the HPW content in the NSs (Fig. S5).This result further proves that the ultra-small HPW clusters have been introduced into the g-C 3 N 4 NSs, forming the 2D HPW/g-C 3 N 4 heterojunction NSs. Photocatalytic activities of the as-synthesized samples for H 2 generation were evaluated under simulated sunlight irradiation by serving triethanolamine (TEOA) as the sacrificial reagent to slake the photoinduced holes.The H 2 generation rates of the as-synthesized samples are summarized in Fig. 7A.It is showed that the H 2 -generation rate of the pure g-C 3 N 4 NSs is 6.6 mol h -1 , and the corresponding turnover number (TON) is 110 based on the used amount of Pt co-catalyst (one H 2 molecule per active metal site 41).Meanwhile, the pure HPW is no photoactivity for H 2 generation, which may be attributed to an improper energy-level of its LUMO with respect to that of H reduction potential 12.Notably, the HPW/g-C 3 N 4 heterojunction NSs show the increased rates of H 2 generation as compared to either the g-C 3 N 4 NSs or HPW hetero-components.It suggests that the static adsorption-deposition of the HPW clusters onto the g-C 3 N 4 NSs can lead to the formation of an effective charge-transfer channel at the intimate interface of the formed HPW/g-C 3 N 4 heterojunction NSs, thus hindering the recombination of photoinduced charge-carriers in the g-C 3 N 4 component.Further investigation found that the H 2 generation rate of the HPW/g-C 3 N 4 heterojunction NSs is dominated by the HPW content in the NSs.When the loading amount of HPW was below 20 wt. in the HPW/g-C 3 N 4 heterojunction NSs, the H 2 -generation rate of the heterojunction NSs increased with increasing the HPW loading.However, a further increase of HPW content (30 wt.) resulted in a decrease of the photocatalytic activity for H 2 generation.This could be ascribed to the fact that the excessive amount of HPW clusters loaded onto the surface of g-C 3 N 4 NSs would shield both the light-absorption and catalytic-active sites nearby the HPW/g-C 3 N 4 hetero-interface regions 28,34,42434445, although a promoted process of charge-transfer may occur in the large-area contact interface between the HPW and g-C 3 N 4 hetero-components.The optimal photocatalytic activity for H 2 generation (14.6 mol h -1 ) was achieved on the 20 wt. HPW/g-C 3 N 4 heterojunction NS (TON 243).Its H 2 -generation rate is 2.2 times higher than that of the pure g-C 3 N 4 NSs.Please note that only 5 mg of 20 wt. HPW/g-C 3 N 4 heterojunction NSs were employed as the photocatalyst for H 2 generation in our work.As shown in Fig. 7B, the H 2 -production yields of all the synthesized g-C 3 N 4 -based samples linearly increase with the irradiation time.After simulated light irradiation for 2 h, the H 2 -generation amount of 20 wt. HPW clusters decorated g-C 3 N 4 NSs could reach 29.2 mol, which is greatly superior to that of the pure g-C 3 N 4 NSs (12.9 mol).It should be pointed out that after assembling HPW clusters onto the g-C 3 N 4 NSs, the specific-surface-areas of the formed HPW/g-C 3 N 4 heterojunction NSs (25.0291 38.5376 m2/g) were similar to that of the pure g-C 3 N 4 NSs (30.2709 m2/g), as shown in Fig. S6.Thus, we believed that the enhanced photocatalytic activity of HPW/g-C 3 N 4 heterojunction NSs for H 2 generation is mainly attributed to the existence of large amounts of uniformly-dispersed and ultra-small sized hetero-interface in the HPW/g-C 3 N 4 heterojunction NSs.The high-quality hetero-interface of HPW/g-C 3 N 4 with a fascinating molecular-scale structure can not only enhance the interfacial chargetransfer process, but also simultaneously offer abundant light-harvesting and catalytic-active sites at the hetero-interface region, thereby enabling a high-efficient utilization of photoinduced electrons for H 2 generation over the HPW/g-C 3 N 4 heterojunction NSs. The g-C 3 N 4 was prepared by a traditional thermal polymerization method.Typically, 10 g of carbamide powder was lapped for 60 min in a mortar and then transferred to a 50 mL alumina crucible with a cover.Subsequently, the crucible was heated to 550 C with a rising rate of 18 C/min and kept for 2 h at 550 C, thereby obtaining the g-C 3 N 4 bulk with faint-yellow color. Typically, 100 mg g-C 3 N 4 bulk was ultrasonically dispersed into the deionized water to form the suspension solution of g-C 3 N 4 NSs.Then, the pH value of g-C 3 N 4 suspension solution was adjusted to 3.1 by dropwise adding 1.2 M of HCl solution.Afterward, 5, 10, 20, 30 mg of HPW were dissolved in deionized water and then added the obtained HPW solution to the g-C 3 N 4 suspension solution with vigorous stirring for 2 h.The weight ratio of HPW to g-C 3 N 4 was determined to be 5, 10, 20, and 30 wt., respectively.Subsequently, the mixture was separated by the centrifugal treatment, and dried at 70 C for 12 h to obtain the g-C 3 N 4 NSs loaded with different amount of HPW.Finally, the HPWloaded g-C 3 N 4 NSs were annealed at 300 C for 2 h under the vacuum condition, thereby synthesizing the HPW/g-C 3 N 4 heterojunction NSs. The laser particle size and zeta potential analyzer (Zetasizer SZ-100Z, Horiba) was used to measure the surface charge polarity of the samples.The crystallization and the phase transition were studied by X ray diffractometer (XRD; XRD-6000, Shimadzu) with a Cu K line of 0.1541 nm and the radiation is from 10to 80, at a scanning rate at 2/ min.Fourier transform infrared (FT-IR) spectra were recorded on a Magna 560 FT-IR spectrometer with a resolution of 1 cm -1 .X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) was performed on a VG-ESCALAB LKII instrument with a Mg K ADES (h 1253.6eV) source at a residual gas pressure below 10 -8 Pa.The surface topography and sample thickness of as-prepared samples were studied by atomic force microscope (AFM; Bruker Dimension IconTM).The morphology and structure of the as-prepared samples were observed by scanning electron microscope (SEM; S-4800, Hitachi), transmission electron microscopy (TEM; JEM-2100, JEOL).Thermal gravimetric analysis (TGA) was carried out on a NETZSCH STA 449C thermo-analyzer in air.UV-vis absorption spectra were taken with a Lambda 750 UV/Vis/NIR spectrophotometer (Perkin Elmer, USA).The specific surface areas of the asprepared samples were measured with a Micromeritics ASAP-2020 instrument and analyzed by the Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) method.Decay curves of the as-prepared samples were obtained on a FLS920 fluorescence lifetime spectrophotometer (Edinburgh Instruments, UK) under the excitation of a hydrogen flash lamp with the wavelength at 325 nm (nF900; Edinburgh Instruments).Photoluminescence (PL) spectra were detected using fluorescence spectrophotometer (F-4600, Hitachi) equipped with a 150 W Xe lamp as the excited light source. 5 mg of the as-synthesized samples, 10 mL triethanolamine (TEOA, 15 vol.), and 10 L chloroplatinic acid (H 2 PtCl 6 , 12 mM) aqueous solution were added in a 35 mL quartz reactor, orderly.Then, the quartz reactor was sealed by a rubber plug, following by ventilation with argon gas for 10 min to drive away the residual air.Subsequently, the reactor was exposed under simulated sunlight (300-W Xe lamp, PLS-SXE300UV coupled with the AM1.5 filter).The gas product composition was periodically analyzed by a gas chromatograph (GC) equipped with a thermal conductivity detector (TCD) (Beifen-Ruili Analytical Instrument, SP-3420A). 10 mg of the Pt-loaded sample was dispersed into 2 mL of deionized water to form a suspension.Then, the above suspension was uniformly dropped onto a 2 cm 2 cm glass substrate.As the water solvent evaporated, the film consisted of the Pt-loaded sample was formed on the glass substrate.Afterwards, the glass with the Pt-loaded sample was put into the 35-mL quartz reactor.Before the irradiation, the reactor was infused with high purity CO 2 for 30 min to degas the residual air.Meanwhile, 0.1 mL of deionized water was injected into the reactor for providing the water vapor.Finally, the reactor loading with the Ptloaded sample was exposed under a 500 W Xe lamp (PLS-SXE300UV).The gas products were periodically analyzed quantitatively by a gas chromatograph (GC) equipped with a flame ionization detector (FID) and a thermal conductivity detector (TCD) (Beifen-Ruili Analytical Instrument, SP-3420A). light source.context: Rational assembly of small-sized photosensitizers onto 2D semiconductors can effectively promote the photocatalytic activity of the formed 2D heterojunction photocatalyst due to the hetero-interfacial charge-transfer process.However, the achievement of the 2D semiconductor-based heterojunction photocatalyst with the exposures of both abundant light-harvesting and catalytic sites at the hetero-interface region is still a huge challenge.Herein, we synthesized phosphotungstic acid/graphitic carbon nitride (HPW/g-C 3 N 4 ) heterojunction nanosheets (NSs) with the highly-dispersed distribution of ultra-small HPW clusters (12 nm) by using a facile self-assembly method based on the static adsorption-deposition process.The formed molecular-scale heterointerface between HPW clusters and g-C 3 N 4 NSs resulted in the exposure of abundant active-sites on the highlydispersed HPW/g-C 3 N 4 hetero-interface.By combining the steady-state and transient photoluminescence spectra with the wavelength-controlled experiments, we demonstrated that the hetero-interfacial charge-transfer process occurring in the HPW/g-C 3 N 4 heterojunction NSs obeyed the Z-scheme mechanism rather than the common "type-II" heterojunction mechanism.In this way, the lifetimes of photoinduced electrons on the conduction band of g-C 3 N 4 could be prolonged for initiating the photocatalytic solar-to-fuels conversion.Upon interband excitations of both the two hetero-components in the HPW/g-C 3 N 4 heterojunction NSs, the photocatalytic activities of H 2 generation and CO 2 reduction could be enhanced by 2.2 and 6.7 times as compared to the pure g-C 3 N 4 NSs, even though the HPW component was photocatalytic-inert for either H 2 generation or CO 2 reduction upon UV-vis light irradiation.

The g-C 3 N 4 was prepared by a traditional thermal polymerization method.Typically, 10 g of carbamide powder was lapped for 60 min in a mortar and then transferred to a 50 mL alumina crucible with a cover.Subsequently, the crucible was heated to 550 C with a rising rate of 18 C/min and kept for 2 h at 550 C, thereby obtaining the g-C 3 N 4 bulk with faint-yellow color. Typically, 100 mg g-C 3 N 4 bulk was ultrasonically dispersed into the deionized water to form the suspension solution of g-C 3 N 4 NSs.Then, the pH value of g-C 3 N 4 suspension solution was adjusted to 3.1 by dropwise adding 1.2 M of HCl solution.Afterward, 5, 10, 20, 30 mg of HPW were dissolved in deionized water and then added the obtained HPW solution to the g-C 3 N 4 suspension solution with vigorous stirring for 2 h.The weight ratio of HPW to g-C 3 N 4 was determined to be 5, 10, 20, and 30 wt., respectively.Subsequently, the mixture was separated by the centrifugal treatment, and dried at 70 C for 12 h to obtain the g-C 3 N 4 NSs loaded with different amount of HPW.Finally, the HPWloaded g-C 3 N 4 NSs were annealed at 300 C for 2 h under the vacuum condition, thereby synthesizing the HPW/g-C 3 N 4 heterojunction NSs. According to the first-principles calculations and analyses, we synthesized the HPW/g-C 3 N 4 heterojunction NSs through a facile threestep route (Fig. 2A): (i) the synthesis of the g-C 3 N 4 NSs by combining a traditional thermal polymerization method with the followed ultrasonic exfoliation treatment; (ii) the assembly of highly-dispersed HPW clusters onto the surfaces of g-C 3 N 4 NSs based on the electrostatic interaction force between HPW and g-C 3 N 4 ; (iii) the heat treatment of the HPW-adsorbed g-C 3 N 4 NSs to strengthen the chemical bonding at their hetero-interface, and thus obtaining the HPW/g-C 3 N 4 heterojunction NSs.During the synthesis process, we, at first, adjusted the surface charges of the g-C 3 N 4 NSs into the positive polarity for adsorbing the negatively-charged Keggin units in the aqueous solution.As shown in Fig. S1, the zeta potential of the as-synthesized g-C 3 N 4 NSs depends on pH value of the aqueous solution suspended with g-C 3 N 4 NSs.Particularly, the surface charges of the g-C 3 N 4 NSs could be changed into the positive polarity when the pH value of the suspension solution was adjusted below 4.5.Thus, a homogeneous dissolution of HPW molecules into the above g-C 3 N 4 NSs-suspended solution would induce a self-assembly of highly-dispersed HPW clusters on the surface of the g-C 3 N 4 NSs due to the electrostatic adsorption process between the negatively-charged PW 12 O 40 3-groups of HPW molecules and the positively-charged g-C 3 N 4 NSs.In order to reinforce the hetero-interface quality in the obtained HPW/g-C 3 N 4 composite NSs, the followed heattreatment process was carried out.It could further strengthen the chemical bonding at their hetero-interface, and leading to the formation of the HPW/g-C 3 N 4 heterojunction NSs in the viewpoint of chemical kinetics and solid state physics 23242526. Fig. 2B shows the X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns of the as-synthesized samples.For the sample of the g-C 3 N 4 NSs, two diffraction peaks appear at 13.1and 27.4, which can be indexed to the (100) and (002) planes of g-C 3 N 4 , respectively 7,8,15,27.For the sample of HPW, the diffraction peaks at 1012, 1622, 2330and 3140a re attributed to the typical HPW with a Keggin structure, which have ever been reported in previous literature 15.However, the characteristic diffraction peaks of HPW could not be observed in the XRD patterns of HPW/g-C 3 N 4 heterojunction NSs, even though the mass ratio of HPW to g-C 3 N 4 was increased from 5 wt. to 30 wt..This phenomenon may be attributed to the fact that the ultra-small sized HPW units were highly dispersed on the surface of the g-C 3 N 4 NSs, thereby leading to a poor crystal-diffraction signal beyond the XRD probing limit. In order to ensure the co-existence of HPW and g-C 3 N 4 component in the heterojunction NSs, we investigated the Fourier transform infrared (FT-IR) spectra of the as-synthesized samples (Fig. 2B,C).For the pure g-C 3 N 4 NSs, the peaks located at 3400 cm -1 to 3000 cm -1 are attributed to stretching vibration of -NH 2 and NH amino groups, while several weak peaks ranging from 1700cm -1 to 1120 cm -1 are assigned to the stretching vibration modes of CeN and CN bonds in CN heterocycles.And, the peak at 812 cm -1 is related to the feature vibration mode of s-triazine ring unit 17,28.In the case of HPW, the feature vibration modes of keggin units are located at 1080.1 cm -1 , 981.76 cm -1 , 889.18 cm -1 , and 802.38 cm -1 , which denote the P-O a bonds of the PO 4 tetrahedron, the W O d bonds, and the two W-O b/c -W bonds, respectively 17.After coupling HPW with g-C 3 N 4 , the characteristic vibrational peaks related to both the g-C 3 N 4 NSs and HPW could be found simultaneously on the FT-IR spectrum of the formed HPW/g-C 3 N 4 heterojunction NSs.As compared to the pure HPW, the three characteristic peaks related to Keggin units (WO d bonds, and two WeO b/c eW bonds) are shifted to 979.83 cm -1 , 893.04 cm -1 , and 812.03 cm -1 , respectively, on the FT-IR spectrum of the HPW/g-C 3 N 4 heterojunction NSs.This phenomenon suggests the existence of chemical interaction between HPW and g-C 3 N 4 in their heterojunction NSs produced by the static adsorption-deposition method and subsequent vacuum annealing treatment. To determine in-depth the chemical interaction between the HPW and the g-C 3 N 4 components in their heterojunction NSs, the X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) analyses of the as-synthesized samples were implemented.As observed in Fig. 3A, three feature peaks, corresponding to sp 2 CeC bonds (284.6 eV), sp 3 -coordinated carbon bonds (285.4 eV), and N-bonded sp 2 C-atom in the s-triazine (NeCN) (287.8 eV) 29,30, can be detected on the C 1s core-level spectrum of the pure g-C 3 N 4 NSs.However, the feature peaks of the sp 3 -coordinated carbon bonds and the NeCN bonds on the spectrum of the 20 wt. HPW/g-C 3 N 4 heterojunction NSs shift to the higher binding energy side as compared to the corresponding peaks of the pure g-C 3 N 4 NSs.In addition, a new peak with the binding energy at around 286.2 eV was observed, which could be ascribed to the formation of CeO bands 31,32.Fig. 3B displays the N 1s core-level spectra of the 20 wt. HPW/g-C 3 N 4 heterojunction NSs in comparison with the g-C 3 N 4 NSs.It is obvious that the binding energies of the sp 2 -bonded N (CeNC), tertiary nitrogen N-(C) 3 groups, and amino groups (CeNeH) 8,33,34 on the spectrum of the heterojunction NSs are also higher than the corresponding energies on the spectrum of the pure g-C 3 N 4 .The O 1s core-level spectra of the pure HPW and the 20 wt. HPW/g-C 3 N 4 heterojunction NSs are given in Fig. 3C.The two feature peaks on the spectrum of the pure HPW are originated from to the WeOeW (530.8 eV) and WeOeP/WeOeH bonds (531.9 eV), respectively 17.In the case of 20 wt. HPW/g-C 3 N 4 heterojunction NSs, the above two peaks also shift toward the higher binding energy side as compared to the pure HPW.Interestingly, the two new peaks attributed to the CeOeW (532.6 eV) and C(N) 3 -OH (533.7 eV) bonds 17,18,35, can be found on the O 1s core-level spectrum of the heterojunction NSs.The appeared C(N) 3 -OH bonds in the 20 wt. HPW/g-C 3 N 4 heterojunction NSs could be attributed to the substitution of the amino groups by the hydroxyl groups after the acidizing treatment of g-C 3 N 4 NSs 17,18, thereby leading to the formation of N defects.Meanwhile, the observation of the CeOeW bond is consistent with the DFT calculation results, further confirming that the HPW and g-C 3 N 4 in their heterojunction NSs are linked by the CeOeW bond.Notably, the W 4f 7/2 and W 4f 5/2 peaks of the pure HPW located at 35.8 and 37.9 eV 17,18, respectively, are shifted to the lower binding energy sides after forming the HPW/g-C 3 N 4 heterojunction (Fig. 3D).According to the previous reports, the binding energy shifts on the XPS spectra of the HPW/g-C 3 N 4 heterojunction NSs can be ascribed to the electron transfer across the HPW/g-C 3 N 4 hetero-interface through the formed CeOeW bond due to the different electron concentration between the two heterocomponents.Additionally, the P 2p core-level signal could be also detected on the XPS spectrum of HPW/g-C 3 N 4 heterojunction NSs, as shown in Fig. S3.The binding energy peak centered at 133.8 eV indicates the existence of P 5 in the oxidation state 15,18, which is in agreement with the valence state of P in the HPW.It further demonstrates that the HPW/g-C 3 N 4 heterojunction NSs were constructed through the self-assembly method based on the static adsorption-deposition process. The light absorption properties of the as-synthesized samples were investigated through UV-vis adsorption spectra, and the corresponding results were shown in Fig. 6 and S5.It can be observed that the pure g-C 3 N 4 NSs possess a broad light-absorption range spanning from UV-to visible-light region.However, the pure HPW only displays a UV-light adsorption property.The band gap (E g ) values of the pure g-C 3 N 4 NSs and HPW were calculated to be 2.75 eV and 3.01 eV, which are consistent with the literatures 12,40.After coupling the g-C 3 N 4 NSs with the HPW clusters, the formed HPW/g-C 3 N 4 heterojunction NSs exhibited the blue-shifts of absorption edges as compared to the g-C 3 N 4 NSs.What' more, the blue-shift phenomenon for the absorption edge of the HPW/g-C 3 N 4 heterojunction NSs increased gradually with increasing the HPW content in the NSs (Fig. S5).This result further proves that the ultra-small HPW clusters have been introduced into the g-C 3 N 4 NSs, forming the 2D HPW/g-C 3 N 4 heterojunction NSs. photoinduced holes.The H 2 generation rates of the as-synthesized samples are summarized in Fig. 7A.It is showed that the H 2 -generation rate of the pure g-C 3 N 4 NSs is 6.6 mol h -1 , and the corresponding turnover number (TON) is 110 based on the used amount of Pt co-catalyst (one H 2 molecule per active metal site 41).Meanwhile, the pure HPW is no photoactivity for H 2 generation, which may be attributed to an improper energy-level of its LUMO with respect to that of H reduction potential 12.Notably, the HPW/g-C 3 N 4 heterojunction NSs show the increased rates of H 2 generation as compared to either the g-C 3 N 4 NSs or HPW hetero-components.It suggests that the static adsorption-deposition of the HPW clusters onto the g-C 3 N 4 NSs can lead to the formation of an effective charge-transfer channel at the intimate interface of the formed HPW/g-C 3 N 4 heterojunction NSs, thus hindering the recombination of photoinduced charge-carriers in the g-C 3 N 4 component.Further investigation found that the H 2 generation rate of the HPW/g-C 3 N 4 heterojunction NSs is dominated by the HPW content in the NSs.When the loading amount of HPW was below 20 wt. in the HPW/g-C 3 N 4 heterojunction NSs, the H 2 -generation rate of the heterojunction NSs increased with increasing the HPW loading.However, a further increase of HPW content (30 wt.) resulted in a decrease of the photocatalytic activity for H 2 generation.This could be ascribed to the fact that the excessive amount of HPW clusters loaded onto the surface of g-C 3 N 4 NSs would shield both the light-absorption and catalytic-active sites nearby the HPW/g-C 3 N 4 hetero-interface regions 28,34,42434445, although a promoted process of charge-transfer may occur in the large-area contact interface between the HPW and g-C 3 N 4 hetero-components.The optimal photocatalytic activity for H 2 generation (14.6 mol h -1 ) was achieved on the 20 wt. HPW/g-C 3 N 4 heterojunction NS (TON 243).Its H 2 -generation rate is 2.2 times higher than that of the pure g-C 3 N 4 NSs.Please note that only 5 mg of 20 wt. HPW/g-C 3 N 4 heterojunction NSs were employed as the photocatalyst for H 2 generation in our work.As shown in Fig. 7B, the H 2 -production yields of all the synthesized g-C 3 N 4 -based samples linearly increase with the irradiation time.After simulated light irradiation for 2 h, the H 2 -generation amount of 20 wt. HPW clusters decorated g-C 3 N 4 NSs could reach 29.2 mol, which is greatly superior to that of the pure g-C 3 N 4 NSs (12.9 mol).It should be pointed out that after assembling HPW clusters onto the g-C 3 N 4 NSs, the specific-surface-areas of the formed HPW/g-C 3 N 4 heterojunction NSs (25.0291 38.5376 m2/g) were similar to that of the pure g-C 3 N 4 NSs (30.2709 m2/g), as shown in Fig. S6.Thus, we believed that the enhanced photocatalytic activity of HPW/g-C 3 N 4 heterojunction NSs for H 2 generation is mainly attributed to the existence of large amounts of uniformly-dispersed and ultra-small sized hetero-interface in the HPW/g-C 3 N 4 heterojunction NSs.The high-quality hetero-interface of HPW/g-C 3 N 4 with a fascinating molecular-scale structure can not only enhance the interfacial chargetransfer process, but also simultaneously offer abundant light-harvesting and catalytic-active sites at the hetero-interface region, thereby enabling a high-efficient utilization of photoinduced electrons for H 2 generation over the HPW/g-C 3 N 4 heterojunction NSs. interfacial charge-transfer pathways in the heterojunction NSs (traditional "type II" heterojunction or direct Z-scheme mechanism), depending on the Fermi-level positions of the single HPW and g-C 3 N 4 components 464748495051.As shown in Fig. S7, if the Fermi-level of g-C 3 N 4 NSs is higher than that of the HPW, the electrons on the Fermi-level of g-C 3 N 4 NSs will transfer to the Fermi-level of HPW for balancing the Fermi-level of the HPW/g-C 3 N 4 heterojunction system.This electron transfer process creates a built-in electric filed at the HPW/g-C 3 N 4 hetero-interface with the vector direction from the g-C 3 N 4 to HPW sides.In this way, the formed interfacial built-in electric filed would drive "type II"-heterojunction charge-transfer process, where the photoinduced electrons transfer from the CB of g-C 3 N 4 to the LUMO of HPW, while the photoinduced holes migrate from the HOMO of HPW to the VB of g-C 3 N 4 .However, the LUMO energy-level of HPW component is below According to the first-principles calculations and analyses, we synthesized the HPW/g-C 3 N 4 heterojunction NSs through a facile threestep route (Fig. 2A): (i) the synthesis of the g-C 3 N 4 NSs by combining a traditional thermal polymerization method with the followed ultrasonic exfoliation treatment; (ii) the assembly of highly-dispersed HPW clusters onto the surfaces of g-C 3 N 4 NSs based on the electrostatic interaction force between HPW and g-C 3 N 4 ; (iii) the heat treatment of the HPW-adsorbed g-C 3 N 4 NSs to strengthen the chemical bonding at their hetero-interface, and thus obtaining the HPW/g-C 3 N 4 heterojunction NSs.During the synthesis process, we, at first, adjusted the surface charges of the g-C 3 N 4 NSs into the positive polarity for adsorbing the negatively-charged Keggin units in the aqueous solution.As shown in Fig. S1, the zeta potential of the as-synthesized g-C 3 N 4 NSs depends on pH value of the aqueous solution suspended with g-C 3 N 4 NSs.Particularly, the surface charges of the g-C 3 N 4 NSs could be changed into the positive polarity when the pH value of the suspension solution was adjusted below 4.5.Thus, a homogeneous dissolution of HPW molecules into the above g-C 3 N 4 NSs-suspended solution would induce a self-assembly of highly-dispersed HPW clusters on the surface of the g-C 3 N 4 NSs due to the electrostatic adsorption process between the negatively-charged PW 12 O 40 3-groups of HPW molecules and the positively-charged g-C 3 N 4 NSs.In order to reinforce the hetero-interface quality in the obtained HPW/g-C 3 N 4 composite NSs, the followed heattreatment process was carried out.It could further strengthen the chemical bonding at their hetero-interface, and leading to the formation of the HPW/g-C 3 N 4 heterojunction NSs in the viewpoint of chemical kinetics and solid state physics 23242526. Fig. 2B shows the X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns of the as-synthesized samples.For the sample of the g-C 3 N 4 NSs, two diffraction peaks appear at 13.1and 27.4, which can be indexed to the (100) and (002) planes of g-C 3 N 4 , respectively 7,8,15,27.For the sample of HPW, the diffraction peaks at 1012, 1622, 2330and 3140a re attributed to the typical HPW with a Keggin structure, which have ever been reported in previous literature 15.However, the characteristic diffraction peaks of HPW could not be observed in the XRD patterns of HPW/g-C 3 N 4 heterojunction NSs, even though the mass ratio of HPW to g-C 3 N 4 was increased from 5 wt. to 30 wt..This phenomenon may be attributed to the fact that the ultra-small sized HPW units were highly dispersed on the surface of the g-C 3 N 4 NSs, thereby leading to a poor crystal-diffraction signal beyond the XRD probing limit. In order to ensure the co-existence of HPW and g-C 3 N 4 component in the heterojunction NSs, we investigated the Fourier transform infrared (FT-IR) spectra of the as-synthesized samples (Fig. 2B,C).For the pure g-C 3 N 4 NSs, the peaks located at 3400 cm -1 to 3000 cm -1 are attributed to stretching vibration of -NH 2 and NH amino groups, while several weak peaks ranging from 1700cm -1 to 1120 cm -1 are assigned to the stretching vibration modes of CeN and CN bonds in CN heterocycles.And, the peak at 812 cm -1 is related to the feature vibration mode of s-triazine ring unit 17,28.In the case of HPW, the feature vibration modes of keggin units are located at 1080.1 cm -1 , 981.76 cm -1 , 889.18 cm -1 , and 802.38 cm -1 , which denote the P-O a bonds of the PO 4 tetrahedron, the W O d bonds, and the two W-O b/c -W bonds, respectively 17.After coupling HPW with g-C 3 N 4 , the characteristic vibrational peaks related to both the g-C 3 N 4 NSs and HPW could be found simultaneously on the FT-IR spectrum of the formed HPW/g-C 3 N 4 heterojunction NSs.As compared to the pure HPW, the three characteristic peaks related to Keggin units (WO d bonds, and two WeO b/c eW bonds) are shifted to 979.83 cm -1 , 893.04 cm -1 , and 812.03 cm -1 , respectively, on the FT-IR spectrum of the HPW/g-C 3 N 4 heterojunction NSs.This phenomenon suggests the existence of chemical interaction between HPW and g-C 3 N 4 in their heterojunction NSs produced by the static adsorption-deposition method and subsequent vacuum annealing treatment. To determine in-depth the chemical interaction between the HPW and the g-C 3 N 4 components in their heterojunction NSs, the X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) analyses of the as-synthesized samples were implemented.As observed in Fig. 3A, three feature peaks, corresponding to sp 2 CeC bonds (284.6 eV), sp 3 -coordinated carbon bonds (285.4 eV), and N-bonded sp 2 C-atom in the s-triazine (NeCN) (287.8 eV) 29,30, can be detected on the C 1s core-level spectrum of the pure g-C 3 N 4 NSs.However, the feature peaks of the sp 3 -coordinated carbon bonds and the NeCN bonds on the spectrum of the 20 wt. HPW/g-C 3 N 4 heterojunction NSs shift to the higher binding energy side as compared to the corresponding peaks of the pure g-C 3 N 4 NSs.In addition, a new peak with the binding energy at around 286.2 eV was observed, which could be ascribed to the formation of CeO bands 31,32.Fig. 3B displays the N 1s core-level spectra of the 20 wt. HPW/g-C 3 N 4 heterojunction NSs in comparison with the g-C 3 N 4 NSs.It is obvious that the binding energies of the sp 2 -bonded N (CeNC), tertiary nitrogen N-(C) 3 groups, and amino groups (CeNeH) 8,33,34 on the spectrum of the heterojunction NSs are also higher than the corresponding energies on the spectrum of the pure g-C 3 N 4 .The O 1s core-level spectra of the pure HPW and the 20 wt. HPW/g-C 3 N 4 heterojunction NSs are given in Fig. 3C.The two feature peaks on the spectrum of the pure HPW are originated from to the WeOeW (530.8 eV) and WeOeP/WeOeH bonds (531.9 eV), respectively 17.In the case of 20 wt. HPW/g-C 3 N 4 heterojunction NSs, the above two peaks also shift toward the higher binding energy side as compared to the pure HPW.Interestingly, the two new peaks attributed to the CeOeW (532.6 eV) and C(N) 3 -OH (533.7 eV) bonds 17,18,35, can be found on the O 1s core-level spectrum of the heterojunction NSs.The appeared C(N) 3 -OH bonds in the 20 wt. According to the first-principles calculations and analyses, we synthesized the HPW/g-C 3 N 4 heterojunction NSs through a facile threestep route (Fig. 2A): (i) the synthesis of the g-C 3 N 4 NSs by combining a traditional thermal polymerization method with the followed ultrasonic exfoliation treatment; (ii) the assembly of highly-dispersed HPW clusters onto the surfaces of g-C 3 N 4 NSs based on the electrostatic interaction force between HPW and g-C 3 N 4 ; (iii) the heat treatment of the HPW-adsorbed g-C 3 N 4 NSs to strengthen the chemical bonding at their hetero-interface, and thus obtaining the HPW/g-C 3 N 4 heterojunction NSs.During the synthesis process, we, at first, adjusted the surface charges of the g-C 3 N 4 NSs into the positive polarity for adsorbing the negatively-charged Keggin units in the aqueous solution.As shown in Fig. S1, the zeta potential of the as-synthesized g-C 3 N 4 NSs depends on pH value of the aqueous solution suspended with g-C 3 N 4 NSs.Particularly, the surface charges of the g-C 3 N 4 NSs could be changed into the positive polarity when the pH value of the suspension solution was adjusted below 4.5.Thus, a homogeneous dissolution of HPW molecules into the above g-C 3 N 4 NSs-suspended solution would induce a self-assembly of highly-dispersed HPW clusters on the surface of the g-C 3 N 4 NSs due to the electrostatic adsorption process between the negatively-charged PW 12 O 40 3-groups of HPW molecules and the positively-charged g-C 3 N 4 NSs.In order to reinforce the hetero-interface quality in the obtained HPW/g-C 3 N 4 composite NSs, the followed heattreatment process was carried out.It could further strengthen the chemical bonding at their hetero-interface, and leading to the formation of the HPW/g-C 3 N 4 heterojunction NSs in the viewpoint of chemical kinetics and solid state physics 23242526. According to the first-principles calculations and analyses, we synthesized the HPW/g-C 3 N 4 heterojunction NSs through a facile threestep route (Fig. 2A): (i) the synthesis of the g-C 3 N 4 NSs by combining a traditional thermal polymerization method with the followed ultrasonic exfoliation treatment; (ii) the assembly of highly-dispersed HPW clusters onto the surfaces of g-C 3 N 4 NSs based on the electrostatic interaction force between HPW and g-C 3 N 4 ; (iii) the heat treatment of the HPW-adsorbed g-C 3 N 4 NSs to strengthen the chemical bonding at their hetero-interface, and thus obtaining the HPW/g-C 3 N 4 heterojunction NSs.During the synthesis process, we, at first, adjusted the surface charges of the g-C 3 N 4 NSs into the positive polarity for adsorbing the negatively-charged Keggin units in the aqueous solution.As shown in Fig. S1, the zeta potential of the as-synthesized g-C 3 N 4 NSs depends on pH value of the aqueous solution suspended with g-C 3 N 4 NSs.Particularly, the surface charges of the g-C 3 N 4 NSs could be changed into the positive polarity when the pH value of the suspension solution was adjusted below 4.5.Thus, a homogeneous dissolution of HPW molecules into the above g-C 3 N 4 NSs-suspended solution would induce a self-assembly of highly-dispersed HPW clusters on the surface of the g-C 3 N 4 NSs due to the electrostatic adsorption process between the negatively-charged PW 12 O 40 3-groups of HPW molecules and the positively-charged g-C 3 N 4 NSs.In order to reinforce the hetero-interface quality in the obtained HPW/g-C 3 N 4 composite NSs, the followed heattreatment process was carried out.It could further strengthen the chemical bonding at their hetero-interface, and leading to the formation of the HPW/g-C 3 N 4 heterojunction NSs in the viewpoint of chemical kinetics and solid state physics 23242526. In order to ensure the co-existence of HPW and g-C 3 N 4 component in the heterojunction NSs, we investigated the Fourier transform infrared (FT-IR) spectra of the as-synthesized samples (Fig. 2B,C).For the pure g-C 3 N 4 NSs, the peaks located at 3400 cm -1 to 3000 cm -1 are attributed to stretching vibration of -NH 2 and NH amino groups, while several weak peaks ranging from 1700cm -1 to 1120 cm -1 are assigned to the stretching vibration modes of CeN and CN bonds in CN heterocycles.And, the peak at 812 cm -1 is related to the feature vibration mode of s-triazine ring unit 17,28.In the case of HPW, the feature vibration modes of keggin units are located at 1080.1 cm -1 , 981.76 cm -1 , 889.18 cm -1 , and 802.38 cm -1 , which denote the P-O a bonds of the PO 4 tetrahedron, the W O d bonds, and the two W-O b/c -W bonds, respectively 17.After coupling HPW with g-C 3 N 4 , the characteristic vibrational peaks related to both the g-C 3 N 4 NSs and HPW could be found simultaneously on the FT-IR spectrum of the formed HPW/g-C 3 N 4 heterojunction NSs.As compared to the pure HPW, the three characteristic peaks related to Keggin units (WO d bonds, and two WeO b/c eW bonds) are shifted to 979.83 cm -1 , 893.04 cm -1 , and 812.03 cm -1 , respectively, on the FT-IR spectrum of the HPW/g-C 3 N 4 heterojunction NSs.This phenomenon suggests the existence of chemical interaction between HPW and g-C 3 N 4 in their heterojunction NSs produced by the static adsorption-deposition method and subsequent vacuum annealing treatment. In summary, we have successfully synthesized a Z-scheme photocatalyst with the molecular-scale hetero-interface through self-assembly of ultra-small HPW clusters onto g-C 3 N 4 NSs via a facile static adsorption-deposition method.The HPW/g-C 3 N 4 heterojunction NSs possesses significant enhancements for both photocatalytic H 2 generation and CO 2 reduction based on the unique synergistic photocatalysis effect between the abundant surface active-sites, the high hetero-interface quality, as well as the Z-scheme-improved charge-carriers separation process.The as-synthesized 20 wt. HPW/g-C 3 N 4 heteojunction NSs exhibited 2.2 and 6.7 folds on photocatalytic H 2 generation and CO 2 reduction, respectively, as compared to the pure g-C 3 N 4 NSs, even though the pure HPW component was photocatalytic-inert for either H 2 generation or CO 2 reduction upon UV-vis light irradiation.It is anticipated that the designed HPW/g-C 3 N 4 heterojunction NSs may provide new insights for exploring molecular-scale heteropolyacid-decorated 2D layered Z-scheme photocatalysts with high hetero-interface quality and abundant active-sites for photocatalytic solar-to-fuels conversion.
